    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
On Capitol Hill today the FDA came under heavy criticism
  for the way it handled Avandia, the diabetes drug linked to alleged heart
  attack risk. The Government Reform Committee chairman called the FDA’s
  monitoring of the drug’s safety “a major failure of our system.”
  Wyatt Andrews will have more and Nancy Cordes will take a closer look at a
  man who’s risked his career to blow the whistle on dangerous drugs,
  including Avandia.
 
Leaders of eight of the world’s most powerful
  countries are meeting at the Baltic Sea resort town of Heiligendamm,
  Germany,
  for the G8 summit. Our chief White House correspondent Jim Axelrod is
  traveling with President Bush and will brief us on the day’s events.
 
One of the hot topics at the G8 is carbon emissions.
  The United States
  emits the world’s most CO2 – pumping out 5.8 billion metric tons
  of the stuff annually. Just behind the U.S.
  is China.
  Barry Petersen is in Beijing
  and will report on the country’s overwhelming pollution problem and how
  it could be creating a crisis for itself – and the rest of the world.
 
Today marks the 63rd anniversary of D-Day,
  and our Richard Schlesinger has the story of one man who was part of the
  forces that stormed into France.
  It’s unlike any war story you’ve heard before – a story of
  a man, a village and a very memorable cow.
 
 It is also a landmark day for game-show fans.
  After 35 years of Showcase Showdowns and Plinko games, Bob Barker taped his
  last show of the legendary “The Price Is Right” today. Bill
  Whitaker was there for the emotional making of Barker’s final show. 
 
I hope you’ll join us for these stories and
  more,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
